What is the effect of negative-pressure wound therapy (NPWT) on split-thickness skin grafts when used as a bolster?

ðŸŸ¦ Q7 â€” Upper Back Reconstruction (2025)

What flaps are useful for posterior upper trunk defects, and what artery supplies the parascapular flap?
Explanation:
- Posterior upper trunk defects often reconstructed with local/regional flaps due to limited recipient vessels for free flaps
- Latissimus and trapezius flaps: options but require muscle harvest and have seroma risk
- Perforator options: circumflex scapular artery perforator flap, thoracodorsal artery perforator flap
- Parascapular flap: highly useful for upper back, upper extremity, and shoulder defects

Vascular supply
- Parascapular flap is based on the circumflex scapular artery
- Circumflex scapular artery branches from subscapular artery and passes through the triangular space (teres minor, teres major, long head of triceps; does NOT include latissimus dorsi or infraspinatus)

Where do friction blisters form in the epidermis, and what is the recommended management?
Explanation:
- Occur after repetitive mechanical trauma, especially on palms and soles
- Separation occurs within the epidermal stratum spinosum
- Blister fluid = sterile serum with few inflammatory cells (unless secondarily infected)

Management
- Initial treatment of sterile blisters: observation
- Larger painful blisters may be drained for relief, but unroofing is generally not recommended (higher infection risk)
- Unroofing/excision + skin grafting is not indicated for simple friction blisters
- Sterile blisters heal by secondary intention and re-epithelialize
- Secondarily infected blisters â†’ incision and drainage + local wound care

How does female androgenetic alopecia typically present, and what is the recommended first-line therapy?
Explanation:
- Common cause of nonscarring alopecia in women; onset any time after puberty, often around menopause
- Clinical picture: diffuse thinning over central scalp with preservation of frontal hairline (unlike males)
- Only ~1/3 have abnormal androgen levels; evaluate for hyperandrogenic conditions (PCOS, hyperprolactinemia, adrenal hyperplasia, tumors) when indicated
- Dermoscopy: hair miniaturization; biopsy useful to exclude cicatricial alopecia / alopecia areata

Treatment
- First-line: topical minoxidil
- Oral anti-androgens may be added in selected patients
- Low-level laser (light) therapy and microneedling are secondary options
- Hair transplantation considered in advanced disease
- Finasteride is NOT FDA-approved for women with female androgenetic alopecia (off-label only)
